content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="http://mrdata.usgs.gov/carbonatite/carbonatite.xsl"?><record id="10"><country>Brazil</country><cntrycd>BRZL</cntrycd><stprov>Minas Gerais</stprov><depname>Serra Negra</depname><latitude>-18.9202777777778</latitude><latdeg>-18</latdeg><latmin>-55</latmin><latsec>-13</latsec><longitude>-46.8866666666667</longitude><londeg>-46</londeg><lonmin>-53</lonmin><lonsec>-12</lonsec><mintype>s\ufffd\ufffdvite</mintype><oreton>200</oreton><deptype>10</deptype><niobium>0</niobium><ree>0.9</ree><p2o5>0</p2o5><grades>(Kamitani and Hirano, 1990), REE grade approximately calculated</grades><depage>81.6 K-Ar, biotite</depage><agemy>82</agemy><tectset>Cretaceous Alta Parana\ufffd\ufffdba igneous province in the Proterozoic Brasilia belt dividing S\ufffd\ufffdo Francisco craton and Paran\ufffd\ufffd basin</tectset><rocks>carbonatite, dunite, jacupirangite, peridotite, shonkinite</rocks><rocksmap>phyllite, quartzite (Precambrian)</rocksmap><orebody_fm>oval carbonatite-alkaline intrusive complex</orebody_fm><ore_area>65</ore_area><alttype>fenitization (weak)</alttype><altwidth>0</altwidth><comments>200 Mt at 27.63% TiO2 (Kamitani and Hirano, 1990); >3% Re2O3 in concentrate, extracted as byproduct (Orris and Grauch, 2002). Lateritic cover 150 m thick at oval intrusive complex 65 sq. km.</comments><mineral role="ore">anatase</mineral><mineral role="ore">apatite</mineral><mineral role="ore">baddeleyite</mineral><mineral role="ore">perovskite</mineral><mineral role="ore">pyrochlore</mineral><mineral role="ore">th and u minerals (disseminated)</mineral><mineral role="gangue">biotite</mineral><mineral role="gangue">calcite</mineral><mineral role="gangue">quartz</mineral><reference>Gomes, C.B., Ruberti, E., and Morbidelli, L., 1990, Carbonatite complexes from Brazil\ufffd\ufffdA review: Journal of South American Earth Sciences, v. 3, no. 1, p. 51\ufffd\ufffd63.</reference><reference>Kamitani, M., and Hirano, H., 1990, Important carbonatite-alkaline/alkaline complexes and related mineral resources in the world: Bulletin of the Geological Survey of Japan, v. 41, no. 11, p. 631\ufffd\ufffd640.</reference><reference>Orris, G.J., and Grauch, R.I., 2002, Rare earth element mines, deposits, and occurrences: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 02-189, 174 p.</reference><reference>Singer, D.A., 1998, Revised grade and tonnage model of carbonatite deposits: U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 98-235, 8 p.</reference><reference>Ulbrich, H.H.G.J., and Gomes, C.B., 1981, Alkaline rocks from continental Brazil: Earth-Science Reviews, v. 17, p. 135\ufffd\ufffd154.</reference><reference>Woolley, A.R., 1987, Alkaline rocks and carbonatites of the world \ufffd\ufffd Part 1: North and South America: London, British Museum (Natural History), 216 p.</reference></record>
